thread.title: Australia needs a space program: Ziggy Switkowski
thread.title_full: Australia needs a space program: Ziggy Switkowski | Business Spectator

author: Mitchell Bingemman
title: Australia needs a space program: Ziggy Switkowski
text:
National Broadband Network chairman Ziggy Switkowski has lamented the absence of a government-funded space program in Australia on the day the mammoth infrastructure builder successfully hurled a satellite hundreds of kilometres above the earth and into orbit.
An Ariane 5 rocket carrying the NBN’s 6.4-tonne satellite roared away from Guiana Space Centre in Kourou, French Guiana, with the thrust of 100 Concordes, yesterday morning.
The launch of the satellite — dubbed Sky Muster — was a complete success, soaring through the atmosphere on the back of the 780-tonne rocket before it was detached after 32 minutes and sent into orbit.
All telemetry systems were tracking perfectly as the NBN satellite entered orbit around the equator. Two arms containing solar panels to power it for the next 15 years unfurled according to plan.
Dr Switkowski attended the launch, describing it as “loud, explosive and muscular”. He later said he was disappointed Australia had not embarked on its own space program, whereas countries such as Argentina had “produced what is demonstrably a successful space program”.
“We do have to question how they have gone about it and can we learn from that process, and I think we can,” he said.
Dr Switkowski said it was ­inevitable NBN would have to either replace the Sky Muster satellite when it ran out of fuel in 15 years or lease capacity from newly launched satellites in order to keep up with the download demands of the bush.
He said it would also be possible to extend the reach of the NBN’s fixed wireless network to the nation’s most rural and remote areas as mobile technologies advanced.
“By then there will be all types of new satellites and new providers. Broadband has become the fundamental infrastructure of the early 21st century so there won’t be any hesitation in staying a bit ahead of the curve,” he said.
“With two satellites I think we have bought ourselves several years. And then in five years’ time, what is the requirement going to be and will there be an experience gap? In the meantime, we are stretching out the fixed wireless network.”
Dr Switkowski said Australia could model a future space ­program on the Argentinian ­approach.
“They haven’t got the formula right yet, but the access to bright people, the nurturing of talent, the ability to put their ­aspirations into worthwhile ­national programs around space and nuclear energy mean that all of a sudden they are a feature on an international scale which we are not,” he said.
